description: I am continually impressed by Builder, and GNOME in general. It's inspiring how dedicated contributors are able to create great, open software ecosystem that is arguably the best.

Skip version 43.1 and stick to the stable RPM version.
Weird graphical glitches that didn't occur on ver 42.

If you're thinking about making an app for GNOME, this is the IDE that you need to use. If you're not, this works for that too. It has all the features that you'd expect from a modern editor, and then some. Debugging, Flatpak, Docker/Podman/Toolbx, and testing on other devices are integrated and built right in, and you really won't need any extra plug-ins other than the ones already provided.
summary: Great general IDE, even better GNOME IDE

description: Awesome, snappy and good looking.
summary: The best IDE for GTK development

description: Amazing application that just need a bit more love.
summary: Overall great, but miss a few features

description: Proses Belajar

Ditched Eclipse CDT for this and never looked back. It's lightweight, integrates well with the desktop, has enough features without feeling overwhelming and the Git support is awesome too. Listing all of the features here will be a waste of time so I'll just say try it if you want to know if it's worth or not.

I can just enter the repository URL of a project and be done with it. In previous versions, build system support wasn't good enough but it's been coming nicely as of the past few releases.

Would honestly recommend it for any C/C++ or JS developers.
Keeps things super clean and simple whilst also maintaining the power of a full IDE. Fully integrates into my system and is very responsive. Perfect for someone just getting into coding.
This is now my default editor since a couple of months back. I appreciate the attention of detail that has been paid to the UI and the easy to use, but powerful, functionality.
Add fuzzy search like sublime/atom. Add more code intelligence/autocomplete.
Love it. Maybe, add some support for automatically adding files to Makefile.am

Great IDE to develop with a lot of languages, a pity groovy is not yet supported, but the app is young, it has to grow.
It cames with VIM modes out of the box (... what more can I say...) 
Highly customizable, lots of settings to help you programming, clean and nice design, a sweet app!
summary: Top IDE, flies like an editor, sting like an IDE

description:
I really like the idea of having GNOME's own IDE, which integrates nicely with the OS. Despite the fact it is in its early stages, I use it daily in my work flow. It still misses a lot of features, but I hope we can see them in the near future.

I am primary interested in Web languages like PHP and Javascript. I would be really nice to have a support for "Go To class definition" for PHP projects and a better auto completion with language specific functions and constructs.
summary: Great app with a lot of potential!

description:
Currently this ide is a nice start. Due to missing web-development tools, I cannot use it. HTML/CSS/JS including autocompletion and project-management should be included.
Furthermore, the different language supports should be an extension and not default. Its a no-go to have vala, python, c-compiler and more installed per default for an IDE.
summary: Nice tool, but needs more default projects

description:
Builder is great and simple to use IDE, it has obvious UI, built-in terminal, devhelp support and it support Meson build system.

All of that is already there for the developer, no need to configure Builder from the ground like some another programs.

I'm using it to develop C + GTK+ apps and it works out of the box.
It is very good.
Since the 3.22 version it's great for creating GTK applications.
I don't fully understand its UI, specially the bottom graph. Plus, I can't remove it.

description: What a fantastic IDE, and it gets better with every release! I'm really excited for its future. I've slowly been transitioning my projects over to using it. If I had to nitpick, it would be about the lack of code folding in the native editor and the lack of a built-in 'snippets' editor/manager. I know these seem like glaring omissions, but, from my understanding, they are coming in future releases. Absolutely a great, and much needed, project. Keep up the good work!!

I've always avoided IDEs and used vim for 17 years now. But recently I started using Builder and it doesn't seem to come in my way like the IDEs I tried in the past, did. I've been using Builder more and more and vim less.

There are a few features I do miss from vim though, e.g markers but having learnt ctrl+o/i, it's becoming less of a problem now than it was at first. Also an issue I have seen in the version I am using (3.26.4 from Fedora 27), is that the `gobject` snippet (that I was very much looking forward to using, does not work (hitting tab doesn't do anything).

summary: Great IDE For C++ or Python

description:
I've been using GNOME Builder as my primary C IDE for a couple years now and it has come a long way in a very short time. If your project is using meson or GObject, it's hands-down the best way to work with it.

I'm docking it one star for what is kind of a nitpick: it has some amazing features that are completely undiscoverable. For example, when creating a GObject, it can generate a template for you completely. However, the only way to discover this is to type the word `gobject` somewhere in the file (without capitals!) and it will add a context menu to add the GObject, with the hint at the bottom, disconnected from the action. This is not mentioned anywhere in the documentation that I can find. It needs better documentation.

Also, I have no idea what other templates are available; a context-sensitive menu (such as right-click) to search through available templates would be a huge improvement.
summary: Excellent for working with C, particularly GObject

description:
This IDE is very underrated in my opinion, its feature rich while being lightweight, i'd wish it would have plugins like vim mode, although i can use it this way, its perfect if you're making GTK/Gnome software.
one of the few great IDE's for C development

This IDE is lightweight and handles writing, building, debugging, profiling, and deploying my 300,000 lines C/C++ project pretty well. It integrates cleanly with CMake, so if you are using that to build and deploy your project from a terminal, it will be able to open and use those files without littering your project directory with more than a single build config file. This config file only records a handful of variables it needs to use the CMake project. If you stick that file in a .gitignore or something so it doesn't get picked up by your version control, you will have a handy IDE with a totally invisible footprint. Very nice.

The interface itself is nice and clean. Fitting with GNOME design, anything that could be labelled superfluous is missing; for the better, in my opinion. I have not missed anything important from the interface, and it is noticeably simpler than Visual Studio, with its endless toolbars, windows, and project options. This IDE gives me what I need and nothing more. Still, I'd like to have an option for horizontal tabs, and there's no way to rearrange them in the vertical list, which seems like an oversight.

I was impressed with the auto-complete features of this IDE. I didn't expect to find this after using Visual Studio for a few years. It's not quite at the level of Intellisense; perhaps as a counterpoint to my last paragraph, there aren't enough configuration options for it, so the auto-complete interferes with my own writing at times, which is a pain. However, its ability to collect information about symbols using Ctags and Clang was unexpected, so I count it as a plus, even though it is not perfect.

I have noticed minor issues after I installed Nemiver for inline debugging. The debugging window gives you the basics: displaying locals, a stack trace, breakpoints, integrating line numbers with the editor, etc. However, you still need to use the integrated terminal to instruct gdb to set a watch or print a specific variable. The terminal interface is also quite barebones and does not even give you a command history. Even worse, the debugger can sometimes hang while you are debugging, leaving it unusable. No idea whether this is the fault of Nemiver, gdb, or Builder, but it is disappointing.

I have not had any issues with the profiler. It seems to do its job well, displaying hotpaths and other useful metrics with minimal performance impact.

I encountered a bug early in my adoption of this IDE as my standard work tool where certain environment variables were not recorded between sessions, so I went to the #builder channel on GNOME's IRC server and informed the maintainers there. They were quick to turn around and fix it, so I appreciate that.

Despite these flaws, I consider this a good IDE. I have used it every day for 6 months and it gets the job done for me. I am hopeful that it continues to be maintained and supported. It does not have very far to go before it can match an IDE like Visual Studio for productivity.
summary: I have used it every day for my 300k C/C++ project for 6 months

description:
cannot get installed, because of unmet depencies; but installer doesn't show which ones...
ubuntu 2020-04 lts
Muy parecido a Visual Studio Code, por lo que hacer la transición desde Windows a Linux utilizando Builder me fue muy facil.

No se puede enfatizar lo suficiente: GNOME Builder es un excelente entorno de desarrollo.

Aprovecha al máximo los elementos gráficos de GTK+ para proveer de una experiencia sencilla, intuitiva, fluida, personalizable, estética; y en general, agradable y productiva; ello sin consumir casi recursos del sistema (unos 100 MB de RAM). No desperdicia ni un píxel del área disponible, a pesar de tener elementos visuales espaciosos, mediante su uso de paneles ocultables y secciones intercambiables. Se integra profundamente con lenguajes populares como Python y C++ (ofreciendo además coloreado de sintaxis para prácticamente todo lenguaje imaginable) y con una paleta de utilidades tal que Sysprof, Git y DevHelp, así como con herramientas de potencial, tal que Flatpak y Rust. Todo ello, disponible libremente y gratis; sin "hacerte tonto" y dependiente de herramientas automatizadas, como la mayoría de entornos de desarrollo.

Si quieres hacer programas para (GNU)Linux y no te gustan editores de texto tradicionales tal que Emacs o Vim, y en especial si quieres trabajar con herramientas del stack de GNOME, prueba ya Builder. Es magnífico; y gracias a su constante desarrollo y extensibilidad, sólo puede esperarse lo mejor.

Si tuviera que pedir algo, sería poder editar archivos de Glade sin tener que abrir la aplicación por separado, con un visor dentro de Builder. Quizás me falte algo de lo que no me he percatado aún, pero desde luego no me ha impedido tener satisfacción y éxito trabajando.
summary: El mejor EID/IDE que he usado

description: El avance de este proyecto es grandioso, se nota el trabajo detrás de él y en poco tiempo será en definitiva, la gran IDE de GNOME.

La verdad me gusta que GNOME desarrolle sus propios programas las considero simples (solo lo necesario) pero potentes, incluso mas que las de licencia no libre.

En una instalación limpia de Debian 9 , Nuevo proyecto usas la plantilla Gnome y tira error al constuir, si es un entorno de productividad al menos la plantilla debe andar, no dan ganas ni de sentarse a problarlo.
Tiene una interfaz limpia, algo muy valioso entre tanto IDE sobrecargado de opciones de dudosa utilidad.

Recien instalada (Al igual que el SO) falla al crear el proyecto y se cierra.Vuelves a abrirla (Carga lenta) y al seleccionar uno de los archivos del proyecto nuevo tarda unos 6 segundos en mostrarlo.
